View_Interfaces

Interface IView

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.util.Observer
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    IActualStateEditView, IAdditionTab, ICostEstimationEditView, ICostEstimationShowView, ICostEstimationTab, ICustomerTab, IDialog, IErrorDialog, IFileChooser, IFRequirementEditView, IFRequirementShowView, IFRequirementTab, IGlossaryTab, IInfoDialog, ILoadingDialog, INFRequirementEditView, INFRequirementShowView, INFRequirementTab, IOptimizedWeightFactorsView, IProcessClassificationView, IProductApplicationTab, IProductDataEditView, IProductDataShowView, IProductDataTab, IProductEnvironmentTab, IProjectCreateView, IProjectTab, IProjectView, IQualityRequirementTab, IRequirementFormView, IRequirementShowView<RequirementType>, IStartView, ITab, ITableTab, ITargetDefinitionTab, ITextTab, IWarningDialog, IWeightFactorEditView
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    ActualStateEditDialog, AdditionTab, CostEstimationEditView, CostEstimationShowView, CostEstimationTab, CustomerTab, DialogView, ErrorDialog, FileChooser, FormWindow, FRequirementEditView, FRequirementTab, GlossaryTab, InfoDialog, LoadingDialog, NFRequirementEditView, NFRequirementTab, OptimizedWeightFactorsView, ProcessClassificationFReqView, ProcessClassificationNFReqView, ProcessClassificationProdDataView, ProcessClassificationView, ProductApplicationTab, ProductDataEditView, ProductDataTab, ProductEnvironmentTab, ProjectCreateView, ProjectTab, ProjectView, QualityRequirementTab, RequirementFormView, StartView, TableTab, TabPanel, TargetDefinitionTab, TextTab, WarningDialog, WeightFactorEditView

    public interface IView
extends java.util.Observer
    Basic interface which provides a standard structure for views.

    To simplify and support the compatibility and modularity of model, view and controller, this interface contains certain methods which every view has to implement. This includes:

    • showView() - makes the view visible on the screen
    • bringToFront() - brings view to the front of all views. Used for show the user a certain view that is already open.
    • destruct() - sets view invisible and disposes it.
    • getViewMenu() - gives the menu bar which belongs to this view.
    Please look at the corresponding methods for details.

    The usage of views can be summed up in a short API (see below)
    API:
    //Creating model object as "myModel" and pass it to the view
    IView myView = new IView(myModel,...);
    ...//preparations before view is shown
    myView.showView();
    ...
    //if view should get in front again
    myView.bringToFront();
    ...
    //if view is no longer needed und should be closed
    myView.destruct();

    Every view need a model object to get the data which it should present to the user. In order to update its fields if the model changes this interface extends the standard Observer interface. The model itself has to inherit from Observable to let the views observe the model.

    A IMenuBar belongs to each view. Due to mostly the menu bar is shared between different views they both are separated and should be separately controlled. The function getViewMenu() returns the menu bar which belongs to this view object.

    Version:
    1.1
    Author:
    9045534
    See Also:
    IViewController, ActionListener, WindowListener, Observer

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void addController(IViewController newController)
      Adds a controller as ActionListener to every button and as WindowListener to the frame if supported by the view.
      void bringToFront()
      Brings view to the front to be shown to the user.
      void destruct()
      Sets view invisible and disposes it.
      IMenuBar getViewMenu()
      Returns the menu bar which belongs to this view.

      • Methods inherited from interface java.util.Observer

        update

    • Method Detail

      • addController

        void addController(@NotNull
                   IViewController newController)
        Adds a controller as ActionListener to every button and as WindowListener to the frame if supported by the view.
        Parameters:
        newController - Controller that should be added to the view

      • showView

        void showView()
        Sets a created view visible. Splits the creation and setting visible to give the controller more flexibility.

        Caution:
        This method can internally be executed either in a different thread for performance or by blocking the current thread (e.g. for IErrorDialog). Please have a look at the belonging documentation of the certain view interface.

      • destruct

        void destruct()
        Sets view invisible and disposes it. Should be called if it not needed anymore.

        Caution:
        This method is not called if the user closes the view by himself. If the controller needs to react on such an event it can do so by implementing the WindowListener and overwritting the corresponding methods.

      • bringToFront

        void bringToFront()
        Brings view to the front to be shown to the user.

        Caution:
        This method has only functionality if the view is shown already (showView() has to be executed). Otherwise it will stay invisible for the user.

      • getViewMenu

        @Nullable
IMenuBar getViewMenu()
        Returns the menu bar which belongs to this view.

        Caution:
        If no menu bar is used for a view this method will return a null value. Please test this value on null before using it further.

        Returns:
        Menu bar which belongs to the view
        See Also:
        IMenuBar
